awd_titl_txt: Cybersecurity Big Data and Analytics Sharing Platform
awd_abstract_narration:
Cybersecurity has become a significant issue that presents new challenges to individuals, industry, and government. To help deal with complex cybersecurity challenges, the international Intelligence and Security Informatics (ISI) community has published high-impact, Big Data driven cybersecurity research since 2003. Despite the many novel advances in data-driven cybersecurity research, there is no sharing platform that aggregates and provides data and tools used and developed in cybersecurity research for the larger cybersecurity community. The proposed project aims to fill this gap by developing the Cybersecurity Big Data and Analytics Sharing Platform to encourage cybersecurity researchers to share their data, tools, and analytical approaches. In addition, the project will support two Security Big Data and Analytics Sharing Workshops to engage the community in the platform development. Upon project completion, the platform will be open for access by the broad cybersecurity research and education community.

The proposed data sharing platform would enable the publication of high-impact, reproducible, and cutting edge research to advance scientific discoveries. Such a platform would also enhance the educational experience for cybersecurity students, specifically CyberCorps SFS students as they prepare to enter the cybersecurity workforce. The proposed project will provide value to both cybersecurity researchers and students by providing data for cutting-edge research and enhanced educational experiences. In addition, this project will also have significant value to government agencies and other organizations interested in developing cyber threat intelligence knowledge. The project team will consist of leading scholars in Big Data Security.

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: University of Arizona, Management Information Systems Department

por.por_cntn:
Outcomes Report

Cybersecurity has rapidly grown to become a societal issue in recent years. The National Science Foundation (NSF) has increasingly focused on developing mechanisms to share cybersecurity data to facilitate Big Data analysis. The objectives of this project were threefold. First, we sought to collect large quantities of cybersecurity data from a variety of sources, including from the Dark Web and the Surface Web. Second, we aimed to build a platform that stored these data to allow the larger cybersecurity community to access to support their research and education needs. Finally, we aimed to execute community development activities to help foster a culture of cybersecurity data sharing. We describe the key developments from each significant activity below.

In the data collection aspect of our project, we collected data from various Dark Web and Surface Web platforms that are often understudied in cybersecurity research and education activities. From the Dark Web, we collected data primarily from hacker forums, DarkNet marketplaces, carding shops, Internet-Relay-Chat (IRC) channels, and Paste Sites. Towards the end of the project, we developed approaches to update the collection on an ongoing basis automatically. The Dark Web collection helps to facilitate research and education efforts, specifically in the growing area of cyber threat intelligence (CTI). Regarding the Surface Web collection, we gathered records from various social media platforms, including MyLife, Spokeo, and BeenVerified. The data collected in these platforms could be correlated with the Dark Web data to enhance CTI or to help facilitate privacy analytics-oriented research. In total, our data collection efforts resulted in over 1.2 billion records of data. In addition to supporting various research activities for the growing cybersecurity Big Data community, the collections provided valuable content for Ph.D. and MS students in the University of Arizona?s NSF CyberCorps Scholarship-for-Service (SFS) program as they conducted their independent studies or dissertation research. The data was also integrated into UArizona?s top-ranked MS in Cybersecurity courses, including CTI and Cyberwarfare.

With respect to the platform development component of our project, we aimed to integrate the aforementioned collections into two major long-standing and highly-visible NSF-funded portals: the AZSecure Data Infrastructure Building Blocks for Intelligence and Security Informatics (DIBBs-ISI) and the AZSecure Hacker Assets Portal (HAP). The AZSecure DIBBs-ISI portal incorporated most of our Dark Web collections, including hacker forums, DarkNet marketplaces, and carding shops. Each data collection on the DIBBs-ISI portal is accessible via a Zip or archive format and is accompanied by a summary of the metadata (key attributes or features) and coverage (e.g., size, date range). The AZSecure HAP was initially designed for CTI-related research. As such, the collections included in this platform comprised over one million records drawn from hacker forums and DarkNet marketplaces. In contrast to the DIBBs-ISI portal, the HAP also consists of advanced deep learning-based algorithms designed to help categorize the data into significant groupings (e.g., exploit types). The HAP also provides a set of visualizations that allow users to efficiently search, sort, and browse for data of interest.

In the final aspect of this project, we sought to help develop a community of practitioners and researchers engaging in cybersecurity Big Data analytics. To this end, we hosted a series of community development activities at major conferences. In particular, we launched and maintained three sets of community events. First, we held a Cybersecurity Big Data Workshop at the 2017 Women in Cybersecurity (WiCyS) Conference. WiCyS is the premier conference for encouraging women to join the cybersecurity workforce. Second, we develop a Cybersecurity Big Data Symposium at the Hawaii International Conference on Systems Sciences (HICCS), the largest conference for system sciences. The symposium offered scholars an opportunity to present their work that leveraged our data collected and potentially identify other data sources of possible interest from the community. Finally, we engaged with the IEEE Intelligence and Security Informatics (ISI) conference, the premier venue for security informatics-related research. The DIBBs-ISI provided a valuable repository for scholars engaging in ISI-related research to access data to support their activities and an archive for researchers to contribute their data (e.g., phishing websites, malware binaries).


Last Modified: 06/29/2022
Modified by: Hsinchun Chen
